title: What would we benefit from if we discover the theory of everything? - Quora

response.answer_text: One of the immediate benefits would be to end the experiments that the theory predicts a negative result. For example, string theory predicts that an elementary particle that exists as a magnetic monopole can exist. Gordon’s Theory of Everything reveals that it is not possible for an elementary particle to exist as a magnetic monopole. The negative results of trying to find one doesn’t prove anything. Gordon’s Theory of Everything also predicts that the LHC will never produce data in the way of smashing particles that will help in finding new math and a path to solve the theory of everything. Please refer to this paper entitled, Why Can’t the LHC Find New Math? Gordon’s Theory of Everything does predict that a neutrino/anti-neutrino interaction will not result in the destruction of these particles because they are both composed of E1 energy. So the immediate benefit would be to stop wasting money on experiments that will get us nowhere. Finding the theory of everything would be important in planning new experiments because if something cannot be derived from the theory of everything, then it does not represent reality.

Not much benefit from the discovery BUT lots of extraordinary benefits if the theory allows us to make more efficient and creative use of nature. It is, of course, the use that we might be able to make of such a theory that enables mankind to progress. Some successful theories are more useful than others. Theories that predict new effects that can be utilised widely are much better than those that give nothing new. It may be that reality is boring and has no more surprises for us but, more likely, surprises are almost always hidden just beneath the surface. Maxwell's theory of electromagnetism gives us a theory predicting email radiation and all that follows.

Well physics, chemistry, engineering, and whole host of other disciplines would make great advancements within a few years. Then we would realize the “Theory of Everything” is incomplete. So our Theory of Most Things while very useful will not be the end all. The entire universe is a very big place. So big we haven’t been able observe most of it. In fact so big the mere speck of time we have had to observe has clouded our objectivity. We believe we have been able to see enough to extrapolate universal knowledge. I know this may be an unpopular opinion, but hubris doesn’t accept that which does not fit into the current meme.

The “Theory of Everything” is a misnomer. It isn’t really a theory of “everything”, it’s a theory that combines quantum mechanics with relativity and thus accounts for all the fundamental “forces” of nature as far as they’re known. If physicists succeed in finding a TOF, they will rejoice. The immediate practical implications aren’t clear but I would assume some of the first things to show up would be improvements in electronics and power sources.

Absolutely nothing. The search for the TOE is a pure academic search. We already cannot make use of the heavier side of the standard model (charm, strange, bottom, and up quarks; the tau lepton; the Higgs; ). Anything we learn new from the TEO must be in scale order of magnitude smaller then the standard model, hence completely out of reach of technology. You can claim about the indirect effect of the search itself (educating students than moves into other fields, the merits of the search on the society etc). However I seriously doubt if such effect can be truly measured to a narrow field of science as the TOE.
